posts.name: Eitan Vichik
posts.cooked:
Recently, my team and I have been trying to implement simulations into our robot software. We got everything to work, including autonomous drive routines, but for some reason the keyboard just doesn’t work. When I run the simulation and connect the keyboard to port 0 in the simulation GUI, it registers the values from the keyboard. However, it doesn’t get to the drivetrain. The function in the drive that the command calls has been tested before, and it works. The GenericHID input from the keyboard is declared in the compile time of the command.

Here is the command: KeyboardDriveSim.java (1.0 KB)

I tried deleting all other GenericHID objects in the code, including an Xbox controller that was connected to port 0, but that had no effect. The axis indexes are correct (according to the sim GUI). Here is a screenshot of the sim GUI window: image 1889×990 97.8 KB

image 1889×990 97.8 KB

image 1889×990 97.8 KB

Has anyone run into this issue before, and knows what to do?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: You have your keyboard as “joystick” 16, 17, and 18. Are those the numbers you’re using in code?  If youre expecting it to function as a direct replacement for a gamepad/xbox controller/etc, then it needs to be one of 1-4, and be configured with the right number of buttons/axes (see the pane in the bottom left for configuration).

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
EitanVichik:

The function in the drive that the command calls has been tested before, and it works.

Are you sure that the command is being scheduled and executed properly? That would be the next thing to check, if the function that the command calls works.

Fletch1373:

You have your keyboard as “joystick” 16, 17, and 18

Those are just the numbers in the list of system joysticks that the simgui presents- the OP has put “keyboard 0” into joystick slot 0 as shown in the joysticks window.

posts.name: Eitan Vichik
posts.cooked:
Ryan_Blue:

Are you sure that the command is being scheduled and executed properly? That would be the next thing to check, if the function that the command calls works.

I’m sure

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Perhaps a silly question, are you enabling the sim robot? (upper left corner in the pic you sent)

posts.name: Eitan Vichik
posts.cooked: It isn’t functioning as a replacement. I just created a GenericHID object, and I’m using the raw axis values.

posts.name: Eitan Vichik
posts.cooked: Yes

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: We need to see your whole codebase then.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Ryan_Blue:

Those are just the numbers in the list of system joysticks that the simgui presents- the OP has put “keyboard 0” into joystick slot 0 as shown in the joysticks window.

you’re 100% right… I’ve apparently completely forgotten how to use simgui in the last couple months.

posts.name: Eitan Vichik
posts.cooked: Here is the link GitHub - Galaxia5987/Sim-bot-2023

posts.name: Eitan Vichik
posts.cooked: Ah hold on, i forgot to push the changes. It will take me a couple hours until i can do that.

posts.name: Eitan Vichik
posts.cooked: I uploaded the updated version of the code.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: It looks like your default command is still XboxDrive. Is that the one you want to use with the keyboard?

posts.name: Eitan Vichik
posts.cooked: Ah hold on, I’ll change it to the correct one. I changed it, the changes should be visible soon.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: If you test the code now, does the keyboard work?

posts.name: Eitan Vichik
posts.cooked: No, still doesn’t move

posts.name: Eitan Vichik
posts.cooked: Um, well this is embarrassing. It turns out you have to be on the sim GUI window in order for the values to actually register. All this time I’ve been switching to my AdvantageScope window so that I could see the drivetrain moving.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: If you have a USB game controller at home, you can use the “Use Real DriverStation” checkbox when starting sim and it won’t require you to be focused on the DS or the sim window to use the controller in sim.

posts.name: Eitan Vichik
posts.cooked: Yeah for some reason the controller works anyway. But I wanted to have the option of a keyboard so that we wouldn’t have to depend on USB controllers.

data.title: Using keyboard to drive in simulation

accepted_answer.excerpt: Um, well this is embarrassing. It turns out you have to be on the sim GUI window in order for the values to actually register. All this time I’ve been switching to my AdvantageScope window so that I could see the drivetrain moving.
